description: An interaction between a patient and healthcare provider(s) for the purpose of providing healthcare service(s) or assessing the health status of a patient.

properties.name: Encounter
properties.short: An interaction during which services are provided to the patient
properties.definition: An interaction between a patient and healthcare provider(s) for the purpose of providing healthcare service(s) or assessing the health status of a patient.

properties.name: id
properties.short: Logical id of this artifact
properties.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
properties.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

properties.name: meta
properties.short: Metadata about the resource
properties.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

properties.name: implicitRules
properties.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
properties.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
properties.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

properties.name: language
properties.short: Language of the resource content
properties.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
properties.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

properties.name: text
properties.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
properties.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
properties.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

properties.name: contained
properties.short: Contained, inline Resources
properties.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
properties.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

properties.name: extension
properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: modifierExtension
properties.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: identifier
properties.short: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
properties.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

properties.name: status
properties.short: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
properties.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.
properties.comment: Note that internal business rules will determine the appropriate transitions that may occur between statuses (and also classes).

properties.name: statusHistory
properties.short: List of past encounter statuses
properties.definition: The status history permits the encounter resource to contain the status history without needing to read through the historical versions of the resource, or even have the server store them.
properties.comment: The current status is always found in the current version of the resource, not the status history.

properties.name: id
properties.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: modifierExtension
properties.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: status
properties.short: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
properties.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.

properties.name: period
properties.short: The time that the episode was in the specified status
properties.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified status.

properties.name: class
properties.short: Classification of patient encounter
properties.definition: Concepts representing classification of patient encounter such as ambulatory (outpatient), inpatient, emergency, home health or others due to local variations.

properties.name: classHistory
properties.short: List of past encounter classes
properties.definition: The class history permits the tracking of the encounters transitions without needing to go  through the resource history.  This would be used for a case where an admission starts of as an emergency encounter, then transitions into an inpatient scenario. Doing this and not restarting a new encounter ensures that any lab/diagnostic results can more easily follow the patient and not require re-processing and not get lost or cancelled during a kind of discharge from emergency to inpatient.

properties.name: id
properties.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: class
properties.short: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +
properties.definition: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

properties.name: period
properties.short: The time that the episode was in the specified class
properties.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified class.

properties.name: type
properties.short: Specific type of encounter
properties.definition: Specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
properties.comment: Since there are many ways to further classify encounters, this element is 0..*.

properties.name: serviceType
properties.short: Specific type of service
properties.definition: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided (e.g. cardiology).

properties.name: priority
properties.short: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
properties.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

properties.name: subject
properties.short: The patient or group present at the encounter
properties.definition: The patient or group present at the encounter.
properties.comment: While the encounter is always about the patient, the patient might not actually be known in all contexts of use, and there may be a group of patients that could be anonymous (such as in a group therapy for Alcoholics Anonymous - where the recording of the encounter could be used for billing on the number of people/staff and not important to the context of the specific patients) or alternately in veterinary care a herd of sheep receiving treatment (where the animals are not individually tracked).

properties.name: episodeOfCare
properties.short: Episode(s) of care that this encounter should be recorded against
properties.definition: Where a specific encounter should be classified as a part of a specific episode(s) of care this field should be used. This association can facilitate grouping of related encounters together for a specific purpose, such as government reporting, issue tracking, association via a common problem.  The association is recorded on the encounter as these are typically created after the episode of care and grouped on entry rather than editing the episode of care to append another encounter to it (the episode of care could span years).

properties.name: basedOn
properties.short: The ServiceRequest that initiated this encounter
properties.definition: The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).

properties.name: participant
properties.short: List of participants involved in the encounter
properties.definition: The list of people responsible for providing the service.

properties.name: id
properties.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: type
properties.short: Role of participant in encounter
properties.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
properties.comment: The participant type indicates how an individual participates in an encounter. It includes non-practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the practitioner roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

properties.name: period
properties.short: Period of time during the encounter that the participant participated
properties.definition: The period of time that the specified participant participated in the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounter's period.

properties.name: individual
properties.short: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
properties.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.

properties.name: appointment
properties.short: The appointment that scheduled this encounter
properties.definition: The appointment that scheduled this encounter.

properties.name: period
properties.short: The start and end time of the encounter
properties.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.
properties.comment: If not (yet) known, the end of the Period may be omitted.

properties.name: length
properties.short: Quantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
properties.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
properties.comment: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.

properties.name: reasonCode
properties.short: Coded reason the encounter takes place
properties.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
properties.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

properties.name: reasonReference
properties.short: Reason the encounter takes place (reference)
properties.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
properties.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

properties.name: diagnosis
properties.short: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter
properties.definition: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter.

properties.name: id
properties.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: condition
properties.short: The diagnosis or procedure relevant to the encounter
properties.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis. The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.
properties.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

properties.name: use
properties.short: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge …)
properties.definition: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge …).

properties.name: rank
properties.short: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type)
properties.definition: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type).

properties.name: account
properties.short: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter
properties.definition: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter.
properties.comment: The billing system may choose to allocate billable items associated with the Encounter to different referenced Accounts based on internal business rules.

properties.name: hospitalization
properties.short: Details about the admission to a healthcare service
properties.definition: Details about the admission to a healthcare service.
properties.comment: An Encounter may cover more than just the inpatient stay. Contexts such as outpatients, community clinics, and aged care facilities are also included.The duration recorded in the period of this encounter covers the entire scope of this hospitalization record.

properties.name: id
properties.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized

properties.name: preAdmissionIdentifier
properties.short: Pre-admission identifier
properties.definition: Pre-admission identifier.

properties.name: origin
properties.short: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission
properties.definition: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission.

properties.name: admitSource
properties.short: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
properties.definition: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer).

properties.name: reAdmission
properties.short: The type of hospital re-admission that has occurred (if any). If the value is absent, then this is not identified as a readmission
properties.definition: Whether this hospitalization is a readmission and why if known.

properties.name: dietPreference
properties.short: Diet preferences reported by the patient
properties.definition: Diet preferences reported by the patient.
properties.comment: For example, a patient may request both a dairy-free and nut-free diet preference (not mutually exclusive).

properties.name: specialCourtesy
properties.short: Special courtesies (VIP, board member)
properties.definition: Special courtesies (VIP, board member).

properties.name: specialArrangement
properties.short: Wheelchair, translator, stretcher, etc.
properties.definition: Any special requests that have been made for this hospitalization encounter, such as the provision of specific equipment or other things.

properties.name: destination
properties.short: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged
properties.definition: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged.

properties.name: dischargeDisposition
properties.short: Category or kind of location after discharge
properties.definition: Category or kind of location after discharge.

properties.name: location
properties.short: List of locations where the patient has been
properties.definition: List of locations where  the patient has been during this encounter.
properties.comment: Virtual encounters can be recorded in the Encounter by specifying a location reference to a location of type "kind" such as "client's home" and an encounter.class = "virtual".

properties.name: id
properties.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.short: Additional content defined by implementations
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: location
properties.short: Location the encounter takes place
properties.definition: The location where the encounter takes place.

properties.name: status
properties.short: planned | active | reserved | completed
properties.definition: The status of the participants' presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.
properties.comment: When the patient is no longer active at a location, then the period end date is entered, and the status may be changed to completed.

properties.name: physicalType
properties.short: The physical type of the location (usually the level in the location hierachy - bed room ward etc.)
properties.definition: This will be used to specify the required levels (bed/ward/room/etc.) desired to be recorded to simplify either messaging or query.
properties.comment:
This information is de-normalized from the Location resource to support the easier understanding of the encounter resource and processing in messaging or query.

There may be many levels in the hierachy, and this may only pic specific levels that are required for a specific usage scenario.

properties.name: period
properties.short: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
properties.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

properties.name: serviceProvider
properties.short: The organization (facility) responsible for this encounter
properties.definition: The organization that is primarily responsible for this Encounter's services. This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different, such as if the actor performing the services was from an external organization (which may be billed seperately) for an external consultation.  Refer to the example bundle showing an abbreviated set of Encounters for a colonoscopy.

properties.name: partOf
properties.short: Another Encounter this encounter is part of
properties.definition: Another Encounter of which this encounter is a part of (administratively or in time).
properties.comment: This is also used for associating a child's encounter back to the mother's encounter.Refer to the Notes section in the Patient resource for further details.

searchParameters.description: A date within the period the Encounter lasted
